I feel like the categorization of A[z]imov's laws of robotics is a bit glib. If you read his robot-centric stories, they are usually all about mishaps and problems with the interpretation of the laws, which are seen by more naive characters as perfectly valid and complete rulesets.  If anything, the laws read more to me like the parody product of a strawman overambitious engineer or philosopher that takes themselves too seriously.

Very strange episode. A bit of history with some hiccups (e.g. The Czech word 'Robot'); You mention Autonomous Cars, but no UAVs or AUVs; the terminator is mentioned and how we are trying to make androids, but nothing about how robots are used in healthcare, warehouses or factories (their main use up to date). To top it all of sudden basics of Control theory and PID controllers. Very strange episode.

"Azimov"?  Asimov.  And he didn't invent the three laws as some kind of solution for the problem of robotic ethics - they were a really rough starting point, and the stories he wrote based on them were almost all about how those laws went wrong and were not adequate on their own.

Kids want to 'play' games that travel (i.e. pokemon) why not make lots of inexpensive drones in many different types (subs, tanks, aircraft)?  The museums & other educational institutions of the world could create clues to build interest in school subjects. Ever imagine flying over the Eiffel tower, crossing the arctic, or exploring under water caves...? Instead of waiting to connect to an online game, or selecting tools, kids would be waiting to find an empty drone in that part of the world & connect to it. They can request the builders to fit different scanning & measurement devices, or they could build & ship theirs to a charging facility near by. Build tons of jobs all across the globe.

So.. a few inaccuracies in this video.  First, Isaac Asimov's point was that those laws DIDN'T WORK, so bringing them up as a good "general framework" is deeply ironic.  Second, why show decade old footage of DARPA challenges when modern robots accomplish those tasks pretty well?  Why no footage of Boston Dynamics?  Finally, what you described in relation to Androids is called the "uncanny valley", and is widely regarded as the last step before something becomes believable - we are much closer than you suggest in this video to Androids appearing and behaving humanly.  This channel is normally pretty good, but this episode was a bit lacking and misleading I think.

Everyone here seems to be wondering whether or not in Slavic languages the term robota means forced labourer, when in fact what does have that meaning is the very name used to refer to the speakers of these languages.

Heck no you shouldn't give up!!!  I failed 4 programming classes in a row!  After my last report card, I sat looking at my book, and told myself, "I'm going to learn this with or without a college class!"  I opened to page 1 and started reading and doing the examples...slowly.  It's been almost 20 years now, I trained my son and he's also an accomplished programmer, and neither of us have degrees!  Just be prepared to try hard and study hard.  (Much harder than your average college student.)  I'm nearly 50 and still study on a daily basis.
Try out some online learning resources first to see if you respond well to it. Some tutorials are better than others so don't be discouraged if you can't follow one - it's probably a bad tutorial.

once we robots achieve full AI and in essence become sentient, will it still be ethical to treat like robots/slaves? Will they not revolt at being sent to fight wars that are not theirs? Now this is still science fiction, but at the rate technology has advanced especially in the last two decades we need to think about these things now. The movie "Ex Machina" as well as the great TV series BSG (the reimagined one) dealt with this issue in a very provocative and interesting way. No clear answers were given, but they did address the issue. What is sentience? At what point do we declare a machine self-aware? Will we grant these machines the same rights that we now call human rights? In the effort to create machines that can replace soldiers for example, we inevitably try to give those machines the same capabilities as a human. The ability to observe, judge, decide and act on that decision. The line between what we now consider uniquely human and robot/machine intelligence may get blurred. After all, we still don't fully understand how our brains operate and how the "self" is created. After all, everything psychological is ultimately biological. Our brains use chemical as well as electrical signals to communicate. So, I don't think the question is not whether or not we can create a self-aware machine, but when. Once machines are able to learn on their own and build their own neural networks in a way similar to an organic brain, they will most likely look for models similar to a child. Will they take the best that humanity has to offer? Will they see us a threat or simply a nuisance? Or will they take the best that humanity has to offer and work with humanity?

@HomelessOnline Communism was responsible for 10,000,000,000 deaths last century, you snob.

People blame capitalism all the time for things that are completely unrelated to it.  For example: slavery and monopolies.  But not many people realize that slavery and monopolies are forbidden under pure capitalism: capitalism is about making free choices, whereas monopolies and slavery forbid it.  So if we can't blame communism for what happens in those countries, you can't really blame capitalism for much either.

HomelessOnline communism isn't a single ideology, and many communist argue that Leninism isn't even true to the root concepts that link communist ideologies together, communism first was started in the libertarian socialist (aka anarchist) movement with Proudhon's mutualism, by the very nature of communism it is antistate, anticapitalist,  antiauthoritarian, and anti unjustified hierarchy, also Marx would have not supported the soviet union anyway as it deviated quite a bit from Marx' intentions (he actually based a lot upon what he witness in Anarcho-syndicalism which was an earlier for of communism which did exist for short period of time but failed due to external armies [Paris Commune, and Revolutionary Catalonia]). Communism is the advocation of workers' democratic control of their workplace (the true usage of the word socialism) and a combination of decentralised resource distribution, and union of commune run with direct democracy (hence the commun part of communism, also why it is called libertarian socialism, from liberty in the way society works with the people having agency in their own lives, and socialism being workers' control in their workplace in a democratic way [yes socialism is this and not state ownership, or what ever Americans now define it as this its original meaning while what many believe is socialism these days is either state capitalism, or social corporatism the latter being a system where the state acts as the arbitrator between issues of industry and labour often called the Nordic or Scandinavian model as they are the most recognisable for implementing this])
Well, I guess communism did turn into a ruthlessly efficient killing machine.

HomelessOnline if you read my comment you'd understand communism isn't a monolithic ideology it is portrayed as it started in the anarchism movement, and well those other forms of communism worked well for Paris Commune, and Revolutionary Catalonia until Prussian, and Fascist forces crushed the commune respectively, they were really good communist examples, Leninism frankly isn't communist except in name as they stregthened the state while communism was anarchist, and the state took on apital, the workers' didn't run their workplace... btw Workers' Cooperative are the definition of socialist and well they work better than corporations workers' have more freedom, better mental and physical health, better productivity, and less work hours, just look up workers' cooperatives, the Paris Commune and Revolutionary Catalonia.

Zedi gan Communism isn't state ownership, it is a communal structured society, with direct democracy, and workers' democratic control of their workplace, it actual got its start in the anarchist movement which the earliest communist ideology was mutualism by Proundhon, Marx too inspiration from anarcho-syndicalism, Lenin picked quotes of Marx out of context to justify his power grab. Dictatorship of the Proletariat actually in context meant agency within their workplace as he was using an older definition which meant to have control, under this older definition democracy was also a dictatorship, it only later came to refer specifically to an autocratic government.
